text: MARTIN, good-looking, practised grin, is staring into a bathroom mirror. He is dressed only in a dressing gown. H looks at himself long and hard.

I can explain it because it’s not inexplicable; it’s a logical decision, the product of proper thought. He opens a bathroom cabinet and takes out a nasal hair trimmer. He sticks the nasal hair trimmer into his nose a begins to use it.
MARTIN now has a face full of shaving foam as he carefull shaves with a steel sharp-looking razor.
Simply put, the reason why I want to die is because I don’t want to live. And you can’t get more logical than that. He closes his eyes.
I'm taking all the mystery out of it, aren't I?

MARTIN walks into the living room - he’s now dressed, and dressed well.  2. No. I’d go so far as to say committing suicide is one of the most logical things I’1l ever accomplish. He checks his watch. He exits. The camera stays in the ro MARTIN re-enters and picks up the letter he’s left by the phone. He picks it up and thinks - he puts it back on the mantelpiece.
Martin steps out of his apartment block. A nice apartment block. He thinks and then returns back into it. We stay looking at the door.

Imagine you’re an - assistant bank manager in Guildford offered the job of managing a bank in Sydney. Well, even though it’s a pretty straightforward decision you'd still think for a bit.... Maybe write a pros and cons list. He returns - struggling out, this time with a ladder unde his arm.
On the cons, aged parents who might die when you’re on the other side of the world, friends you’1l miss, and a golf club where you know your handicap is not laughed at.
MARTIN lashes ladder onto the roof of his car. He does energetically and without a great deal of skill.  10

...on the pros, more money, better quality of life, sea, sunshine, women with suntans, a chance to invent yourself as being someone other than an assistant bank manager from Guildford. He stops. He breathes.
He starts the car. He takes a toffee from his glove compartment and shoves it into his mouth.
Now I’m not an assistant bank Manager, I haven’t got aged parents, they’re dead, I don’t play golf, I hate the sport... He backs it out of the drive. He drives down the street.
But eighteen months ago I had everything and then - I met Danielle Thurby. He passes a woman he knows who is wearing devil horns and embarrassed grin. She smiles. And mouths ‘Happy New Year’ waves.
Five feet nine inches. thirty-six double-D. Fifteen years, two- hundred and fifty days old and yet she looked twenty-five if a day. I didn’t even enjoy it. Her. It.

MARTIN parks up the car beside an office block which seem ascend into the sky - this is Toppers Tower. He gets out his car, looks up at the looming building for the briefes seconds, and then starts to unlash his ladder.

And now my wife hates me, I can’t see my kids, I’ve a criminal record, a listing on the national sex offenders register and have so spectacularly pissed away my career that I’m less successful than an assistant bank manager in Guildford.Yup. Suicide is my Sydney.  11 12 13 14 4. He puts the ladder beside the car. He takes a bolt cutter a torch out of the boot. He clips it on a buckle to his trouser belt. He puts the bolt cutter into his back pocke where it sticks out precariously.
No offence intended to the good people of Sydney of course.
MARTIN is waiting for the lift, it arrives. He attempts t put his ladder inside. It doesn’t fit. He tries it another way. It doesn’t fit. He tries it a third way. Yup. Really doesn’t fit.

MARTIN takes the stairs, carrying the ladder, the torch banging against his leg with every step. He looks up the staircase. Only fourteen more flights to go. Only - fourt fourteen - exhaustion awaits.

location: TOPPERS TOWER. TOP OF STAIRCASE. NIGHT 13

Then thinks better of it and takes the bolt cutter out of his pocket and throws it on the floor. He won’t be needing th again. He takes a breath and then walks out through the open doo

The roof has three feet of barbed wire netting around the outside of it, with a metal strut at the edge of the wire MARTIN lays his ladder horizontally so that it traverses the barbed wire. He takes out a cigar. He tucks it behind his ear. He puts the torch in his mouth and begins to crawl out on his ladder. Over the wire. It’s a horrific and vertigo- inducing watch. He wobbles at one point, and clings on, then he steels himself and keeps going. He reaches the end.  5. He carefully manoeuvres himself into seated position. He refocuses himself. He sits as if on the edge of the world, he puts the torch his lap, he doesn’t look down - instead - he takes the ci from behind his ear and lights it.
Um. Excuse me. MARTIN turns and looks at MAUREEN, astonished there is someone else up there with him. MAUREEN is 40-something, has a brave, anxious, smile on her face.
I’m not entirely sure how to phrase this. But... Are you going to be long?
What?
I wasn’t sure whether to wait my turn or....I hadn’t considered the wire. I'd really like to borrow your ladder. If that’s.... There is a moment’s pause.
Maybe I should just wait. I’1l wait.
Right.
Sorry.
No. No. MARTIN turns back to facing the night sky, frowns and tur back to MAUREEN, his concentration gone.
You're just going to stand there and watch are you?
No. No. Of course. You’1l be wanting to do it on your own I'd imagine.
You'd imagine right.  15 16 17
I’ll go over there. She indicates the door. She begins to walk over to it. He half laughs.
I‘1l give you a shout on the way down. MAUREEN attempts half a smile.

Right. MAUREEN stands quietly - looking towards MARTIN and then turns around. He checks what’s she doing and then.... He composes himself. He feels the mood take him. He takes puff of his cigar. He looks out forward, maybe he even lifts himself up ready to propel himself out. And then he drops the cigar - from his mouth. And then reaches out to grab it and in doing so almost overbalance over the edge of the tower. Fuck. It’s a long way down. H grabs the edge and regains his balance.
The cigar tumbles down the side of the building and we go with it. Turning in the night air, our stomachs lurching. drop is further and faster than we’d ever have anticipate
The cigar lands with a bounce. Then it lies still. Then a truck roars over the top of it. The camera closes on a cigar lying brutally flattened on road.
MARTIN wobbles, he looks down. He points the torch down. can’t see the drop. He thinks. He thinks again. He looks down. He announces.
I can’t. Not with you watching.
Oh. He looks at her, she looks at him.
I could leave, come back in twenty minutes... MARTIN thinks and then frowns.
Maybe you should go first? MAUREEN registers this. She thinks. She turns thoughts over in her head.
I’d - want to be on my own. Completely. On my own.
Understood. Twenty minutes. Then I want my spot back. MAUREEN thinks and then nods.

Right. OK. He thinks and then starts crawling back along the ladder. The ladder wobbles again. MARTIN’s survival instinct come in again - he lies still a moment. He looks at MAUREEN. S puts out a hand.
Maureen. MARTIN stands. They shake hands.
Martin.
Are you from... I recognise your face...?
Do you? They realise they’re still shaking hands. They stop.
Were you married to someone in a pop group?
No. MAUREEN remembers.
Were you on TV? She thinks. Slightly excited now.
Mushrooms. You like mushrooms.
Mushrooms?

You said. I remember. There was one of those chefs in the studio - moustache - and he gave you something to taste and you said ‘Mmmm, I love mushrooms, I could eat them all day.’ Was that you? MARTIN digests this.
Maureen. Perhaps now’s not the time for small talk. MAUREEN smiles at MARTIN. She looks at the ladder. She kn what this means.
Well. I’ll...um...

Yes...I’11 just - leave you for - Which is when they hear a door bang behind them. JESS, 18 stands with mascara running down her cheeks. She is dress for a New Year’s Eve party, high heels, the works. She lo at the two of them - confused. She sees the ladder, she frowns, and then she starts runn hard for it. She almost makes it. But MARTIN grabs her by her belt. She kicks him in the face, but he hangs on and pulls her backwards onto the roof.
No. No! He is really having trouble keeping hold of her.
Calm down. Calm down. She wriggles away. She makes for the ladder again, this time he full on rugby tackles her. They fall to the groun with an oooof.
Who the fuck are you? JESS tries to stick her fingers into MARTIN’s eyes. She i wild on something.
Ow! Maureen. Bit of help...
You're getting a thrill out of this aren’t you - pervert! The struggle continues, MAUREEN is anxious not to intervene.
What do you want me...to do? JESS looks up at MARTIN. She recognises him.
Oh my God. You’re Martin Sharp. You are a pervert. Officially.
That’s it! Rise and Shine with Martin and Penny.
Sit on her will you? MAUREEN hesitates, and then sits on Jess, and MARTIN knee on her arms.

Just let me go. Let me go. MARTIN turns and looks at her, amazed at her balls. Then phone begins to ring. And they look to their own phones. MARTIN stands, MAUREEN stands, JESS stands. And they look at each other. It’s no their phones ringing. The phone continues to ring. MARTIN flashes his torch aro the roof looking for the culprit. It alights on...JJ - he sitting cross-legged on the opposite edge of the tower bl He’s wearing a crash helmet and he has an insulated pizza on his lap with ‘Paulo’s Pizzas’ printed on it.
Hi. He talks with an American accent. They all stare at him. thinks and then takes off his helmet - he’s mid-20'’s, sh looking. He shuts off his phone and smiles - unsure.  18 10.
Any of you guys order a pizza?
How long - have you been - there?
I don’t - know. JESS starts to laugh.
Well if you’re here for the death ride ....there’s a queue. TITLES: A LONG WAY DOWN.
They are in exactly the same positions. JESS grins as she looks at the other three.
So do we do introductions...? I’m Jess. People call me Jess.
I’m Maureen.
Jd.
I'm -
Martin Sharp.
Yes.
Quite exciting to have a celebrity in our suicidal midst. The word ‘suicidal’ seems to make everyone wince.

(as if it’s small talk) So - what made everyone chose Toppers Tower?  19 11. No-one says anything. JESS thinks and then takes the pizz from JJ and opens the box. She grins at the contents. She seems to be enjoying herself. None of the others are.
Ham and Pineapple? Really? And it’s cold. No-one fancies jumping down and getting some pepperoni do they? No-one laughs. No-one says anything. JESS looks at them a and begins to eat.
No-one fancies a slice?.. What? Not going to deliver it now is he? MAUREEN looks at MARTIN and then JJ.
This....this feels wrong. JJ looks at MAUREEN. Thinking.

Maybe we could jump together....One. Two. Three. She makes for the ladder. But MARTIN is too quick and kic it out of the way. It falls through the wire and descends heavily to the ground far below. MARTIN watches it...anxiously. It lands with a distant smash - a car ala blares. JESS laughs. Then suddenly it begins to rain. They wait. Looking at ea other. MARTIN looks up at the skies. He thinks.

Nice to meet you - all. He exits the rooftop. He leaves everyone else behind. The remaining three exchange a look - unsure what to do w themselves - and the rain gets heavier still. INT. MARTIN’S CAR. NIGHT 19 MARTIN sits looking numb. He’s numb with shock. His skin a greyish pallor to it. The rain drums incessantly on the windscreen. He turns on radio. He turns it off again. He turns on the windscreen wipers - but they’re slightly broken - there’s a weird pa in the middle of their rotation - oh, and they squeak.  20 21 22 12. MARTIN just looks at the world. And then - suddenly - he hammers the steering wheel with his hand. And then he reg hammering the steering wheel. This is both raw pain and, know, slightly pathetic. MARTIN starts the car. He begins to drive. He drives past MAUREEN standing in the rain at a bus stop She disrupts the thought. He thinks. He stops the car. He looks back at her. He reverses it back.
MAUREEN is standing fastening a carrier bag onto her head a make-shift hood.
Do you want a lift?
No. No. The bus will be along in - fifteen minutes. MARTIN looks at her gruffly.
Get in the car Maureen. MAUREEN thinks and then does.
MAUREEN looks around and smiles at MARTIN, they’re still nervous of each other.

I did like your television show. MARTIN doesn’t answer, they lapse back into silence. They drive past JJ - trying to get a Pizza moped started the rain. MAUREEN looks at JJ. MARTIN looks at MAUREEN. MARTIN stops the car.
Tonight is really not going how I expected.
MARTIN drives past JESS. Who is walking purposively along street.  23 13. MARTIN’s car stops. JESS runs to the car and then looks inside.
Bit early for a reunion isn’t it?
Get in. We’re taking you home.
MARTIN is moderately dry, everyone else looks like drowne rats. They drive in silence.
So this is - jolly...
Maybe we should have some sort of group therapy. Right here. Right now. Maybe that’s what destiny wants. Take a right here. MARTIN does take a right.
OK. One word answers. You can all have one word answers which address exactly why you were up on the roof in the first place. No-one says anything.
To give an example, Martin might say notoriety.
Are you trying to get us to share our feelings? Because I’m not sure this is the best way.
To give another example, Maureen might say loneliness. MAUREEN looks at JESS, hurt.
Is that what you think? JESS turns to JJ. JJ doesn’t want her to turn to him.
And then there’s our pizza boy...  14.
Jd.
Do you mind if I call you pizza boy-
Yeah.
Pizza boy. Why might pizza boy want to die? I’m guessing -
What would be your reason, I can tell you’re dying to tell us?
Dying to tell you? See what he did there? No? My reason....Love. The oldest most fucking chestnutty chestnut of them all. MAUREEN turns - surprised by the swearing.
Chas. He spurned me. I’m a spurned woman. (she smiles broadly) Take a left. MARTIN takes a left.
I am not lonely.
Tell that to your cats.
I don’t have cats. JESS is shocked.
Really? JJ is thinking.
Are we not fitting into your pre- ordained boxes Jess?
Actually you fill your one marvelously - was prison fun?  15.
You really believe you have an answer for everything don’t you?
I really believe you are a miserable bastard.
Actually, right now, a miserable bastard is exactly what I am. Have I not been hiding it well? MAUREEN interrupts.
I was up there because I felt...helpless.
And I was up there because I have cancer. I have inoperable cancer. JESS smiles broadly and punches his arm.
We have a winner. Fucking brilliant. MAUREEN turns - ready to say something about the swearing but she doesn’t.
Very impressed. Embarrassing cancer? JJ hesitates.
Brain. CCR.
Colon would have been better.

Oh, it’s largely self-inflicted, few too many drinks and drugs you know...
Right. Pull up here. MARTIN pulls the car to a stop.  24 25 16. They look up at the squalid house they’re outside of, the listen to the pumping music it’s emitting. There is a par going on.

Well. Good luck with your next attempts. See you in the afterlife. She exits the car.
She stands looking up at the party. And for a moment her is that of a little vulnerable girl - she takes a breath, steels herself, and enters the house.
MARTIN drives with steady intensity. The broken windscree wipers grow ever more annoying.

Where am I dropping you JJ?
I don’t know why she thought I’d have cats and she certainly swears too much. But...  26 27 17. MARTIN looks at MAUREEN.
Go on Maureen... Just say it...

MAUREEN, MARTIN and JJ enter through a broken front door. MAUREEN looks around - extremely worried. It’s a loud and quite aggressive party. It’s full of people who look like they don’t belong anywhere but here and our three stand o like sore thumbs. JJ has to shout over the music.
Martin take the stairs, Maureen take the bathroom, I’1l take the dance floor.

What else we gonna do? JJ heads off into the crowds. MARTIN thinks and then copi JJ's bravery. MAUREEN lingers a moment more - looking immensely uncomfortable - and then follows them both.

Hi. He tries to stop a youth moving through the room. The you looks at MARTIN like he’s pointless. He feels pointless. MARTIN tries again.

Hi. I’m looking for...  28 29 18. Again he’s ignored. MARTIN sits on a sofa. In the backgro we see MAUREEN edging around the edge of the room. A girl sits beside him. She looks at him and then strokes his face.
Hi.
Hi. I’m looking for a girl called... She strokes his face again.
Hi.
Jess. Do you know the name Jess? She looks at him for three seconds, and then instantly falls asleep. On his shoulder. MARTIN looks at her a moment.
Good. Great. Perfect. Then people start chanting.
Ten. Nine. MARTIN realises what’s happening. He extricates himself f the girl and lies her down against the arm of her sofa.
Eight. Seven. He aims for the exit. But he literally can’t get through. MARTIN looks for somewhere to hide. He spots a staircase. He aims up it.
Six. Five. Four. MARTIN takes the stairs two at a time. He opens the exit the top.

MARTIN takes several deep breaths. He really doesn’t want to be here tonight.  19. Then two people come out after him. And he looks for somewhere to hide. He wedges himself beside a sort of gri in the corner.

Three. Two. One. Happy New Year. There’s an audible cheer from the house and the streets outside. There’s an audible cheer throughout London. Fireworks ignite throughout the streets. London is beautiful. The two people kiss. MARTIN winces.
Hey. MARTIN turns, surprised. He didn’t realise he had company CHAS is sort of sitting underneath the grill.
Oh. Um. Hi. Hiding too are you?
Yeah. I mean, sort of - I can’t come into the light.
Is that - comfortable?
You get used to it. I’ve taken some pills. All good. MARTIN laughs, he likes this guy.
What you hiding from?
Oh, you know - humans - humanity - humankind. You? CHAS’s eyes are as round as saucers.
A nutter who is trying to kill me.
Your reason is better than mine then. And where is this - nutter?
She’s everywhere.
She’s God-like? I see.  20.

I'm hoping I’m just having a bad pill. But she’s not supposed to be here and I’m pretty sure I just saw her. Though I’m also pretty sure I’ve seen you on breakfast TV, so maybe...you know, I mean it actually could be a good pill and... I don’t... MARTIN looks at CHAS and then smiles softly.
You’re Chas aren’t you? CHAS looks back and frowns.
How d’you know that?
I’m here with the - nutter. CHAS looks at MARTIN like he’s dangerous, then tries rapidly to escape. This is easier said than done. He bangs his head on the underside of the grill.
Chas. Chas. Listen to me. Let’s go find her together. What’s the worst that can happen? CHAS turns to him with incredulity.
She's tried to kill me twice, got me arrested once. I’m banned from three pubs, two clubs, a cinema, and a hairdressers...
Ok. So the worst that can happen is...bad but... CHAS stops and sways and looks at MARTIN more carefully.
Look. Just let me leave quietly. I did nothing wrong.
Nothing wrong? Taking her to bed. Nothing wrong? MAUREEN appears in the background of shot.  21.
No more drugs for this man. MAUREEN looks at MARTIN and shrugs.
All these people - and you should have seen the toilets- MARTIN smiles acknowledgement.
I’m off -to a monkery - monastery - I’m becoming, you know, a monk.
You owe her the courtesy of talking to her.
She won’t talk! She’ll chase me with a bread knife -
And tonight she was prepared to end her life because of what you did to her. CHAS wobbles. Suddenly sober. MARTIN looks concerned. But MAUREEN is determined to let her bitterness hang on.
What?
Maureen. I think that’s a bit (much).
That’s where we met her. On top of a tower block. Preparing to - you know... MAUREEN is clearly very upset. CHAS wobbles slightly agai
What? Then JJ bursts through the doors. He looks at MARTIN, and then at MAUREEN.
It’s Jess. I think she’s taken an overdose.
JESS is pushed hard through the hospital. She's trying to speak. She’s bucking hard. She’s deathly white. MARTIN follows the trolley. MAUREEN, CHAS and JJ two step behind.
Jess. Jess.
Are you her father? MARTIN is slightly offended by the question.
No. JESS manages to get some words out.
Next of kin? Are you next of kin?
No. No. The trolley is moving quickly, MARTIN has to half run to keep up.
Sir. I need her full name.
I only - she’s called Jess - I didn’t - none of us knew her before tonight. Another nurse is going through JESS’s pockets.
She's got no identification on her. No nothing. MARTIN half-smiles, but not in a good way.
She probably didn’t want to make identification easy....I think she likes things - difficult. The NURSE looks at him coldly.

You need to wait here....  32 33 23. The hospital double doors close on the action. MARTIN stands a moment, unsure whether to force himself in behin them. He looks at his reflection in the glass of the door. He r his face.
Right then.

MAUREEN, MARTIN and JJ sit in a line in a green-soaked waiting room. CHAS is lying on one of the other benches. Curled up. Asleep. With a thumb in his mouth. There is a small television in the corner. Blaring out images of Hogmanay.
Do you think she...do you think she meant it? She doesn’t seem like she meant it. MARTIN looks at MAUREEN.
How do you seem like you mean it? MAUREEN considers the question.
Well. I suppose you go through with it. This is a dark thought. It settles uneasily on the room.

She has. We haven’t. I need some air. JJ stands and walks out. MAUREEN thinks, looks at MARTIN and then follows JJ. MARTIN thinks and then follows MAUREEN. CHAS is left alone. Curled up in foetal position.

MARTIN’s car is parked in an empty car park looking up at the hospital. JJ, MAUREEN and MARTIN stand against it.  34 35 24. MARTIN gets out a cigar and lights it. He hands it wordlessly to JJ. Who takes a puff and hands it to MAUREE who smiles, doesn’t puff and hands it to MARTIN.
The rain’s stopped. MAUREEN checks her watch. MARTIN rubs his eyes and smiles
Late for something? MAUREEN looks at him guiltily.
My son’s home in three hours. And - Matty’s breakfast is quite complicated. MARTIN is surprised.
You have a son? MAUREEN reads his surprise.
I don’t.... If I’m not going to die tonight it’s important he doesn’t know anything - happened. MARTIN nudges MAUREEN, she sees what he sees.

JESS is coming out of the fluorescently tinged hospital, dressed in a gown, wearing nothing on her feet. She sees them looking at her. She pulls a dance move. Saturday Night Fever style. Then she coughs. Then she starts to walk towards them. She walks a little like John Wayne. They watch her approach.
She stands and looks at them a beat. Looked at closely sh has charcoal smears at the corners of her mouth. She smil at them all.  25.
OK. So a few things to clarify. One my gown is open backed because they’ve stolen my clothes, so I’m going to twirl so you can look at my arse once. She twirls. We get a look at her arse.
But please don’t look again. It’s not my best feature. I’m not telling you what that is until I know you better. Two. It wasn’t an overdose. It was an accident.
Jess...

I just took some pills - for fun - and then took some more...I’d never kill myself with pills - jumping off a tower block is way - way - cooler. And then she laughs, but no-one else laughs. Jd We were worried Jess. Her face grows more serious. She looks at JJ.
That’s four. Three. Four. I’m losing count. Thanks. For, you know, caring ....appreciate it.
He was worried, I was trying to work out why we were still here.
And that’s five. Four. Five. Oh, fuck numbers... I’ve been thinking. We’ve gone too far. We need to make a pact.
What?
And six. Is it just me or is it fucking cold out here?  36 26.

MAUREEN, JESS and JJ sit beside a vast open airport-style window looking out on a London vista. MARTIN approaches them carrying two coffees and two cokes stops a moment, looks at them, thinks and then carries on towards them. He sets the drinks down. JESS grabs one of the cans and o it.
When’s the next date? After New Year's Eve? When every one kills themselves?
Why - ?
Valentine’s Day. JESS looks at MAUREEN and smiles, that is a good answer.
That’s six weeks. Here’s the pact: No-one kills themselves until then. There's a brief silence as everyone tries to digest this.
Why? Why would we do that? Why would we not kill ourselves if and when and how we want?

Because we’ve met each other now - because - you stopped me - twice - you Martin. But mostly because - JESS thinks, she’s trying here. She starts to play with t salt and pepper pots in front of her - almost acting out scenario.

You know that bit in films where people fight up the top of the Empire State building - and there’s the bit when the baddie slips off and the hero tries to save him, but the baddie’s sleeve rips off and you hear him all the way down. Aaargh.  27.
You want to watch me - plunge to my doom?
I'd like to know I’ve made the effort. I want to show people I’ve made the effort. There’s a silence. A soft tissue silence.
Besides, what’s the alternative? A race to finish. Me checking the obituaries every week to see if Martin Sharp is dead... She looks at JJ and MAUREEN.
No offence, your deaths won’t make the papers....Think about it. It’s only six weeks. MAUREEN is thinking hard. She looks at JJ, who’s thinking too, and MARTIN, who’s frowning.
It isn’t so ridiculous. And...no- one really knows how I feel except you three so...well.. Just ‘til Valentines Day. I’d like that. JESS turns and smiles at MAUREEN, surprised at her ally.
Thank you Maureen! Who’s got a pen? JJ gets out a pen.
Paper? MAUREEN thinks and pulls out a piece of paper.
Paper. JESS speaks as she writes in a faux posh accent.
The undersigned do hereby promise not to kill themselves until Valentine’s Day. Maureen sign... MAUREEN nods and signs.  28.
Pizza boy sign...
But...
Just do it. You’re dying anyway. Makes no odds to you. JJ thinks, hesitates, looks up at them all as if about to something, and then changes his mind and signs. JESS signs after him.
And then there’s you Martin...life saver. Superman. The two hold eye contact for a moment.
It’s only six weeks. We’1l all push you off the top ourselves at the end of it if that helps... Bea little Valentines’ Day treat.
I'm pretty sure we’re going to live to regret this. JESS grins. MARTIN signs.
Guys. Look. JJ indicates - the sun is coming up. Breaking low over th London landscape. They all turn and stare at it.
(soft, so soft) So it is a new year then?
Yeah. And the four stand together looking up at the dawn sky.
Hang on. Maureen..... Just a fucking question here... JESS has unfolded the piece of paper which they’ve writte their pact upon. MAUREEN turns towards her.
Have we written our pact on your suicide note?  37 38 39 29. MAUREEN blushes and then smiles.
Oh. Yes. There is that. JESS laughs first. Then MARTIN. And then everyone laughs. And properly. And then they stop. Because it sort of isn’ that funny. But the smiles remain.
A hard and heavy pumping beat. This world is visually and rhythmically different to the world we’ve been in. If Martin’s soundtrack was Bruce Springsteen then we’re now the land of Tinchy Stryder.
It surprised me to hear that invisibility is a technical possibility.

You know, I’ve very good reasons to be angry with him so...I don’t know why I always have to be the one trying to mend... Sorry. Sorry. I promised myself I wouldn’t do this. MAUREEN looks at her. CINDY is crying slightly.
My kids need their Dad. And I need to know he’s OK. MAUREEN offers CINDY a tissue. CINDY takes one.
Better take two - they’re the supermarket value kind. They mush when exposed to water. CINDY laughs, despite herself, and then takes two. Then t and looks at MAUREEN cautiously.
Why were you up there? On the - roof. It’s a stark question. MAUREEN thinks about asking for clarification. But she doesn’t.  120 90.
Without me, social services would pay for Matty’s care. The standards they... He wouldn’t have to have me getting everything - (wrong)
You think he’d be better off without his mother?
Not his mother. This mother. CINDY tries to think how to rationalize this, she can’t. stands up.
This was a bad idea. Wasn’t it? Me. Coming here.
Was it?

I wanted you to tell me someone was looking after him. I hoped you were. But why would I expect you to help? You were up there too. CINDY begins to exit then stops. She turns - she looks at MAUREEN a moment.
Thanks for the tea. She exits. MAUREEN is left alone.

I didn’t make you tea. INT. MATTY’S BEDROOM. NIGHT 120 MAUREEN is dressing MATTY in his pyjamas. She unknots his arm to get a pyjama top on to him. He doesn’t resist. He doesn’t make a noise. She forces the top on to him. It’s not an easy business.
Sometimes I think you’re saying something to me. Then I realize you can’t. She sits back.  121 122 123 124 91.

Maybe I’1l just sit here a bit. INT. MATTY’S BEDROOM. NIGHT 121 MAUREEN wakes sitting in exactly the same seat. She clear fell asleep there. MATTY is asleep on the bed. She reaches out as if to touc him, but changes her mind. She stands. She is slightly unsteady on her feet. She walks to the door. She exits. And then she re-enters at speed. She checks MATTY’s breathing. Then she checks it again.
No....No..... She puts an oxygen mask on him, she begins to administer A lady who we haven’t seen much action from at all is suddenly all action. She opens a phone with her mouth. Sh dials 999.
MATTY is pushed along a corridor. NURSES and DOCTORS administer what they can as he moves. MAUREEN runs beside them, totally at a loss.
MAUREEN stands lost, desperate and limp as surgeons administer on her son. Outside the window, snow begins to fall. A NURSE guides her out.

MAUREEN sits on the chairs. It’s early morning. Around he life lives. Maybe it speeds by. Maybe we watch people being wheeled i gurneys and people shouting at vending machines. And drun coming in and out. It’s clearly snowing outside, many loo snowed on, and a familiar sludge forms in the entrance wa  125 92. MAUREEN stands and walks slowly through them to the phone She begins to dial. And priests sit beside her, and breast-feeding Mums and k with angry faces... And then MARTIN enters, looking flustered. He has fresh s on him.

I came as quickly as I could. MAUREEN looks at him - glassy eyed. Emotionless. He hugs And it feels odd because these two lonely people are not to hugging - the hugging is pain and emotion all at once they both sort of sink into it. And then JESS and CHRIS enter and just - watch the hug, slightly uncomfortably. They too have snow on them. MAUREEN looks at JESS - and breaks from MARTIN - slightly astonished.
You came too?
Nothing on the TV. This is my Dad. He drove me. He’ll probably say something moving about loss now. Everyone looks at CHRIS expectantly.
I’m sorry to hear about your son Maureen.
Not one of his better attempts.
I’m really pleased - I’m really - grateful - you’re all - here. JESS looks at MAUREEN - steadily.
Fuck off. Of course we’re here.
Time has passed. MARTIN and CHRIS sit together. MAUREEN slightly apart. JESS enters with a tray of hot chocolates which she distributes.
This isn’t tea.  93.
I know. It’s hot chocolate.
I asked for tea.
Yes. But I was buying. And I don’t like the smell of tea.
So when you buy rounds in pubs..?
Ya-huh. Everyone gets pink gins. And then I never have to buy a round ever again. Clever right? MARTIN smiles. She looks around the room.
Is Double J still not here?
I didn’t get through to him. He’s probably not picked up his messages.
Either that or he doesn’t care. One or the other. MARTIN looks at CHRIS.
I genuinely don’t know how you've survived her...
Ear plugs.
I’m going to make you go and sit in the car in a minute.
Ear plugs and Pink Gin. MARTIN looks at CHRIS and softly smiles.
He wasn’t the reason I was up there. Matty. He wasn’t. The tone suddenly shifts.
No.  94. MAUREEN looks at them all wildly.

There were lots of reasons why I was up on that roof. You once asked me why Jess and I said I felt helpless. But the truth is, I hadn’t done a list for living and a list for.... It was a feeling not a.... thought. But not one of those reasons - was that I didn't love my son. Not one of them. Not one.

Maureen. We know that. For once in her life JESS has been sincere. And it’s nice And then DR STEPHENS appears at the end of the waiting ro and walks slowly towards them. But only MAUREEN notices. And then everyone notices. DR STEPHENS makes eye contact with MAUREEN - she assumes worst.
Oh no. Oh no. No. Don’t tell me.
No. No. He’s fine. Maureen. Maureen. He’s fine. MAUREEN looks up at DR STEPHENS.
What?
We're going to keep monitoring him but he’s no longer critical. He’1l be fine.
He'll be fine?
He'll be fine. MAUREEN looks at him, and her face feels upside down, she not sure how to look. DR STEPHENS (CONT’D) Would you like to come see him?  126 95.
MATTY is lying with lots of tubes sticking out of him. MAUREEN and DR STEPHENS stand at the front. JESS and MART behind. CHRIS behind them.
The tubes look worse than they are. We'll remove some tonight. The rest will hopefully be out tomorrow.
I should have seen it sooner. If he’d had proper care. If he’d had proper care. DR STEPHENS smiles.

Maureen. You saved him. He looks at her. She sits beside MATTY, he thinks about leaving but decides to stay. DR STEPHENS (CONT’D) It was a myocardial infarction. He had a heart attack. Of sorts. His symptoms were almost invisible. I didn’t notice it, I was monitoring it and didn’t... But you caught it. You saved his life. He stops talking. MAUREEN is gently - quietly - singing t MATTY without even realising it. She realises she’s singing and stops. Immediately. Embarrassed. She looks up at DR STEPHENS who smiles gentl back. DR STEPHENS (CONT’D) It’s lovely the way you look at your son. MAUREEN looks up at him - what does that mean? DR STEPHEN ploughs on. DR STEPHENS (CONT’D) He’s calmer when you’re around. You make him - calmer. He seems to - he always knows you’re there. Matty is a very lucky boy to have you. CHRIS takes JESS’s hand. JESS lets him. MAUREEN doesn’t know how to take this at all. MAUREEN tur and looks at DR STEPHENS.  127 96.
I only had one thought - when he - if he dies, I die. DR STEPHENS looks her straight.

Well. He lived. DR STEPHENS makes to exit, and then stops. DR STEPHENS (CONT’D) And maybe he feels the same way about you as you do about him, have you ever considered that? MAUREEN doesn’t move. DR STEPHENS exits. He nods at MARTI he does. DR STEPHENS (CONT’D) Make sure you don’t crowd him. He’1l need lots of rest. MARTIN nods. DR STEPHEN’s exits. MAUREEN stares intently at her son.
Are you calmer when I’m here - are you calmer...? JESS looks at MARTIN, a tear rolls down her cheek.
MARTIN, CHRIS, and JESS stand in the corridor, gathering themselves.
Well, that was....
Yeah. Then a porter comes past pushing a ‘Happy Valentine’s Day decorated trolley.
It’s Valentine’s Day?
No-one send you a card? Pretty girl like you....shame. JESS’s brain churns through all the possibilities.  97.
It’s Valentines Day. Martin. It’s Valentines Day. MARTIN turns and looks at her. It’s not registering.
God, breakfast TV really mushed your brain didn’t it... MARTIN’s face drops.
The pact.

Get Maureen. We need to find JJ. Now. 128 INT. CHRIS’S CAR. DAY 128 JESS sits intently staring through the screen. They’re driving fast through the sludge and the snow of a cold wi day. CHRIS looks at her.
The things Maureen said about her son.....
No time for an emotional now Dad. Things to do. People to save. But CHRIS is emotional.
I’m going to try harder Jess. I’m going to try harder, OK? JESS says nothing. CHRIS looks at her again.

There was something in an article I read recently - about a man who survived jumping off the Golden Gate Bridge. He said that two seconds after jumping he realized there was nothing in life he couldn’t solve - apart from the problem he'd just given himself by jumping off the bridge. He looks at JESS.
Do you think - do you understand that - does that make sense to you?  129 98. JESS says nothing. And then turns to her Dad.
Yeah. It could make sense. A tear leaks down JESS’s face.

Didn't you think - ? With my face in the front of the paper ...That she'd see it and come home... CHRIS’s face suddenly is filled with pain. He battles har keep this emotion from his youngest daughter.
Maybe she’s dead. Maybe she just had enough of us. Maybe she - I don’t know - maybe we need to concentrate on ourselves for a bit. He parks up outside Paulo's Pizzas.

Well. We’re here. JESS looks at the door and then back at her Dad. She kiss him on the side of the cheek and then exits at speed. INT. PAULO’S PIZZAS. DAY 129 JESS races in ahead of CHRIS. She looks at the faces. PAU big and hairy is preparing an order - shoveling tomato on pizza bases.
JJ? We're here for JJ.
JJ? He’s gone.
Gone? Shit.
Prick left a week ago. Didn’t even serve notice. CHRIS looks at PAULO. He puffs up.
The “prick” is my daughter’s friend Paulo. And you’1ll do well to recognise that fact. JESS grins despite her worry. Then CHRIS loses his nerve.  130 131 99.
You are called Paulo, right? PAULO approaches them both and CHRIS really loses his ner
It’s just the place is called Paulo's Pizzas and...you certainly sound Italian and look Italian...not that there’s an Italian ‘look’... You’re quite scary close up.
Come on Dad.... They race out together.
GLADYS walks puffily up the stairs. MAUREEN follows her.
I’m not supposed to...
I’ve been in the paper with him.
I know you have love.
Then you know we know each other. Trust me.
Such a nice boy. GLADYS thinks and then opens the door.
The place is in a total mess. MAUREEN looks at it. Aghast

Oh my. Along one wall is a series of newspaper cuttings. They ha headlines like ‘No Angels here’. They are of other suicid from Toppers. They present a very bleak picture. We close MAUREEN’s eyes as she takes it all in.  132 133 134 100.
MARTIN walks up the stairs. He quickly gets out of breath But he forces himself on.

location: TOPPERS TOWER. TOP OF STAIRCASE. DAY 133

text: The door is bolted. This time with heavier locks. And a s saying ‘Access Prohibited’. And this time MARTIN doesn’t a bolt cutter.

Fuck. He kicks at the door. The door swings open. The bolt has already been got at. Again. MARTIN looks through the door. And only then does he real walking back out on that roof is one of the hardest thing he’1l ever do.

MARTIN walks onto the roof. With bravery we haven’t seen him before. He looks around the snow filled rooftop. Flak still joining it from all sides. In fact, up here, it’s a of a blizzard. Through the white, MARTIN sees someone standing on the ed of the roof. He’s heart broken.
I hoped you wouldn’t be up here. JJ doesn’t turn around.

You know, three people have killed themselves off this building between New Year and today? Sue Chalmott, housewife and manic depressive, David Frommet a banker who'd lost everything, and Ben Peterson, he was only 15. I cut out bits on them in the local paper.
So you're going to - join them?
I kept to the pact. This - me - it’s none of your business now.
True.  101. MARTIN thinks.
One question though - why? JJ thinks - and then thinks again - and then turns and lo at MARTIN, still on the edge of the building.
That's the thing, I didn’t lie to you - I don’t know.
You - don’t know?
Yeah. I don’t - know. And that’s why my reason is better than any of yours.
Better? I wasn’t aware it was a competition.. MARTIN starts to walk towards JJ.
Jess - she just needs to feel important. Maureen - she needs to feel loved. You need to grow a brain.
That’s not - fair...
But me...I’m Dorothy... so how do I get better? What cures me? You can solve your problems. Me? I can’t. MARTIN keeps walking.

Martin - stop walking. You stop walking right now. Otherwise I’1l start walking, OK? Three steps backwards. And I’m - gone. MARTIN stops walking. MAUREEN comes through the rooftop door and makes to speak She sees the scene and doesn’t. JJ doesn’t see her.
I'm bored of being scared all the time and not knowing why. Bored of trying to change - and not knowing how. (MORE)
Leaving my latest shit band, moving countries - because however much I do change I’m left with - me.
Sounds like you've got it all worked out JJ. It’s logical. The reason why you don’t want to die is because you don’t want to live anymore, it’s quite simple, right? JJ says nothing.
Yeah. I used to think like that too. JESS suddenly bursts through the roof doors.
MARTIN turns and silences her with a look.
And then there were four. JJ looks at JESS, he really didn’t want her here. Jd Don’t you get it - we’ve got to Valentine’s Day and nothing - absolutely nothing - has changed.
But - everything - has changed.
We're standing in entirely different positions for one thing. JJ wobbles. He looks at JESS. He wobbles.
And the rest of us - the other three up on this roof - we’re not here because we want to die - we’re here for you. He looks around the rooftop.
I didn’t want to be up here ever again JJ. I’m pretty sure none of us did.
He’s right. It is shit up here.  135 103.
But I am here - we are here. Now. For you. And I’m pretty sure - if you thought about it - you’d do the same for me...for any of us.. MARTIN digests his own words. JJ says nothing.

The Topper House Four. We belong together. We’re a team. We’re the worst team the world has ever known and, if I’d have been picking, none of you would have even made the subs bench but still, we’re a team. JJ looks back at the edge of the tower. We look at the edge of the tower. It’s a long way down. And it’s very very white. He turns - he looks back at MARTIN, JESS and MAUREEN. MAR speaks softly to him.
Not much I know son. But - maybe we're a start. JJ opens his mouth, considering carefully what to say. He clears his throat.
You can’t even see to the bottom. We look down again into the white.
MARTIN parks up his car. And lets his kids - MAISIE and P out of the back. POLLY is carrying a doll. They run excit towards the park. MARTIN follows. There is evidence of sp on the trees.
Maisie, don’t run. Maisie. MAISIE does run. She falls - she scrapes her knee.
Don’t cry. Don’t cry. You’ve just learnt a valuable lesson.. MAISIE does cry. MARTIN helps her clean up her knee.  104.

It’s hard not to consider the notion that I didn’t mean it. The suicide. That none of us meant it. But I did - mean it, I know I did - I scored very highly on Aaron T. Beck’s Suicide Intent Scale. Twenty- one out of thirty points.
MARTIN with MAISIE on his shoulders and POLLY holding han beside him walks through a park. POLLY is talking excited
And then we saw a penguin and Mum said that the penguin is - a nice animal and I said it didn’t look nice.

Yes, suicide had been contemplated more than three hours prior to death, yes, I -- was certain of death even if I received medical attention. It’s fifteen storeys high, Toppers. Yes, there was preparation for the attempt: ladder, bolt cutters, cigar... It’s just these - people - showed up. And I - well, I... He approaches a picnic rug. On it is JESS, MAUREEN and - They look pleased to see him. They’re mid conversation.
Brilliant. I bet Martin will be good at this.
(to MARTIN) Don’t even join in. MAUREEN looks at a child who’s approached her.
Now - are you Maisie or Polly? And would you like a toffee?
What will I be good at? He sits down.  105.
Consider this... Sitting around here. Are other people who’ve - without doubt - contemplated suicide. MARTIN turns to his daughters.
Run off and play.
But Dad -
Now. They do.
Thanks Jess.
(to MARTIN) Don’t engage. Never engage. JJ grins and takes some pills out of his pocket.
Oh, JJ's getting upset. He’s taking his mad pills.
Anti-depressants.
I’ve bought a thermos Martin. Would you like some coffee?
It’s true. Statistically, at least one person on this hill will at some point in his or her life kill themselves...Maureen told us, it was in her quiz book. MAUREEN blushes.
I've joined a team. Just a - small thing. This matters to MAUREEN but no-one else really registers fact.
So - who would you pick? JJ laughs.
Oh, that’s where you were going with it!
Who would I pick?
To die.
Who would I pick to die?
Yes. It’s not a hard question. I think that lady. MAUREEN points out someone walking her dog. The lady noti and frowns. Everyone looks at her - shocked. A drop of ra falls from the sky.
Maureen!
Maureen. I love you. Jd She’s looking. Put your hand down.
What? She doesn’t know what I’m saying. I could be saying who’s got the nicest bottom. It could be a compliment. JESS is delighted. She indicates. More rain falls.
And I say that man - that man in the khaki shorts. Martin. Your turn. The man turns and looks at them.
OK. Now everyone’s looking.
I'm not picking.
Martin, it’s just a game.  107.
Maureen, I’m shocked.
Isn’t it brilliant? I’ve ruined her.
If you're shocked by that John Julius - I can do considerably worse - I’ve remembered my joke about Vaseline. It suddenly starts raining quite heavily. They start to gather their things.
Shit.
Fuck.
The clouds part? Maybe God hates you after all Maureen. Everyone laughs as they put the ground sheet over their h and run for cover, gathering Martin’s children as they do

Yes, there was logic in what I wanted to do. I wanted to say goodbye to a semi-functioning digestive system, a criminal record, a wife who hated me, a job I was shit at and a more than healthy dose of self disgust - I wanted to say goodbye to a life mislaid. No. Not mislaid. That implies accidental damage. I hadn’t mislaid my life, I’d...spent it. Everyone scatters from the hill top. And then MARTIN runs back up - alone - to collect the doll Polly left behind.
But now, if it doesn’t make me sound like a dickhead, I’m going to earn it back.
It does make you sound a bit like a dickhead.
Thanks Jess.  108.
